quoteFirst: She called at Cherbourg the same day, Queenstown Thursday, and left for New York in the afternoon, expecting to arrive the following Wednesday morning. But the voyage was never completed. She collided with an iceberg on Sunday at
quoteLast: in Lat. 41° 46' N. and Long. 50° 14' W., and sank two hours and a half later; 815 of her passengers and 688 of her crew were drowned and 705 rescued by the Carpathia.
title: The Loss of the S. S. Titanic: Its Story and Its Lessons
author: Beesley, Lawrence, 1877-1967

quoteFirst: This time, however, I determined to try. In half an hour I had evolved a plot, such as it was, and at a
quoteLast: the story was finished. A highwayman was its hero and its scene the great North Road in England.

quoteLast: --it must have been that, because Emma heard the stableclock chime the half-hour--Struan was seen in his blacks. He came out of the wood-house, an ashplant in his hand.

quoteFirst: Anyhow, I got back to London feeling a bit sick and wishing I'd fixed up with you, and there was your blessed note sitting in the glass.  I jumped into a cab and came round here at once.  The girl who let me in said you were at some party or something, and that I was to wait and sleep here.  Well, I waited till a
quoteLast: , and then I rang for her and asked her whether you were making a night of it.  She said she didn't know, and she looked so infernally sleepy that I told her she'd better go to bed, and that I'd sit up for you.
title: Another Man's Shoes
author: Bridges, Victor, 1878-1972

quoteFirst: Laverick walked into Luigi’s Restaurant at about a
quoteLast: , and found the place crowded with many little supper-parties on their way to a fancy dress ball. The demand for tables was far in excess of the supply, but he had scarcely shown himself before the head maitre d’hotel came hurrying up.

quoteFirst: By eleven o'clock the hangers-on and idlers began to lounge into the big yard paved with cobblestones. At half past eleven McGaw got out of a buggy, accompanied by Quigg. At a
quoteLast: Tom, in her hood and ulster, walked rapidly through the gate, and, without as much as a look at the men gathered about the office door, pushed her way into the room. Then she picked up a chair and, placing it against the wall, sat down.

quoteLast: . How quiet it is! Only the mellow note of a mavis sometimes in the oak woods, and the clear, high treble of a shilfa, break on the stillness. The tinkle of the little village smithy, down among the trees, is silent. It is the Day of Rest.

quoteFirst: Martelli, in command of a party consisting of C Company and half A Company. The raid was to be carried out against enemy trenches opposite Railway Craters, at
quoteLast: It was carefully practised beforehand over a taped model. Unfortunately, the enemy were evidently aware of our intentions, probably divining that a raid was in prospect from the fact of our having cut gaps in the wire, and whilst our men were forming up in No Man's Land, they suddenly opened an intense bombardment, mostly of gas bombs, which fell right amongst them.
title:

quoteFirst: She had prided herself for years on her ability to set herself to waken any time at all, and never fail to waken on the minute. However that was, it turned out that she slept on straight past seven, past eight, past nine, past ten, past eleven, and never wakened till
quoteLast: o'clock, dazed and vague as to where she was or why she was there.
title: An interrupted night
author: Pansy, 1841-1930; Hill, Grace Livingston, 1865-1947 [Editor]

quoteFirst: Our procession passed on to Middleham railway station, which we reached about a
quoteLast: .  A considerable crowd had assembled about its precincts.  The roadway and the entrance to the station were guarded by a body of mounted police, and a small detachment of the Middleshire Yeomanry in the charge of no less a person than Major George Catesby, who saluted us with his sword.
